claim_cards.claim: A 90-day, falsifiable benchmark protocol is defined to test whether NT + distance-ratio rhythm can beat DNS on lead-time, RMSE, and GPU cost.
claim_cards.test_hook: Run the 90-day phases end-to-end and report lead-time, RMSE, and GPU hours side-by-side vs DNS baseline.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: a 90-day, falsifiable protocol that bets on Narrative Ticks (NTs) and their distance-ratio rhythm to beat DNS

claim_cards.claim: NT is framed as the flip-point where disorder begins to order itself; the benchmark targets detecting the first such flip.
claim_cards.test_hook: Verify the detector marks candidate NTs that align with early regime-change moments in the scalar signal.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: We look for the instant disorder begins to order itself. That flip-point is the NT.

claim_cards.claim: NT distance ratios are proposed as scale-free signatures: distances carry memory, and their ratios cluster when physics repeats.
claim_cards.test_hook: Compute NT-distance ratios; check whether the histogram shows sharp peaks (non-flat) across runs.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: NT distances carry scale-free memory; their ratios cluster when the same physics repeats.

claim_cards.claim: Even with overlapping DU cycles, the same ratio peaks should persist, making ratio-peaks an invariant candidate.
claim_cards.test_hook: Perturb initial conditions / windowing; test whether ratio peaks remain stable.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: Over-lapping DU cycles still share the same ratio peaks — an invariant to test.

claim_cards.claim: The minimal input prerequisite is an HDF5 scalar timeseries G_t (e.g., drag/lift/KE), shape (N,), sampled at uniform Δt, used for NT detection.
claim_cards.test_hook: Validate dataset meets (N,) and uniform Δt; then run nt_detect.py without preprocessing hacks.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: HDF5 file with dataset G_t (drag, lift, KE …) — shape (N,), uniform Δt — the same scalar used in the NT detection.

claim_cards.claim: A 10-minute smoke test is defined: candidate NTs should be visible (red dots) and the ratio histogram should not be flat; sharp peaks indicate signal.
claim_cards.test_hook: Run nt_detect + ratio_quicklook; accept only if histogram is non-flat with peaks.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: histogram should not be flat; look for sharp peaks.

claim_cards.claim: The benchmark is structured into phases with explicit deliverables: NT times, initial ratio scan, σ hyper-search, NT-aware solver runs, KPI calculation, and PR submission.
claim_cards.test_hook: Track each phase output artifact (nt_times.txt, spiky histogram, σ*, forecast CSVs, KPI files, results PR).

claim_cards.claim: The guide sets a KPI gate: lead-time ≥30%, RMSE ≤5%, and GPU cost ≤½ DNS.
claim_cards.test_hook: Compute the three KPIs on the same dataset and compare to DNS baseline; pass/fail against thresholds.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: Target KPI lead-time ≥ 30% • RMSE ≤ 5% • GPU ≤ ½ DNS

claim_cards.claim: σ should be scanned from 1.0 to 2.0 and selected by the clearest ratio peaks (strongest histogram structure).
claim_cards.test_hook: Run σ grid search 1.0–2.0; choose σ* maximizing peak sharpness / contrast.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: Scan 1.0 – 2.0; pick the σ giving the clearest ratio peaks.

claim_cards.claim: A minimal runnable CLI pipeline is specified: clone repo, run nt_detect.py to produce NT times, then run nt_ratio_cli.py to write *_ratios.txt outputs.
claim_cards.test_hook: Execute the exact CLI steps and verify expected output files exist and are non-empty.

claim_cards.claim: If NT-distance ratio peaks stabilize across runs, the guide interprets this as PoLA expressing itself as a minimal-divergence rhythm inside turbulence.
claim_cards.test_hook: Repeat runs (different seeds/windows); test stability of ratio peaks; only then invoke the PoLA interpretation.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: If your NT-distance histogram stabilises around the same ratio peaks across runs, you’re watching PoLA express itself inside turbulence.

claim_cards.claim: Ratios are asserted to be dimensionless and thus comparable across scalars/units (as long as a consistent scalar G(t) is used per run).
claim_cards.test_hook: Confirm that changing units rescales G(t) but leaves ratio histogram unchanged (within numerical tolerance).
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: Units? Any scalar ...; ratios are dimension-less.
